Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modeling-Based Design of Freeze-Cast Hybrid Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The freeze-casting process is one with which bulk materials and entire components of several cubic centimeters in size can be manufactured with ease. The process is based on the solidification of water-based solutions or slurries (suspensions). To freeze-cast a scaffold, a solution or slurry is poured into a mold and then directionally solidified. During freezing, the water solidifies in the form of pure ice crystals, and the polymer that was dissolved and the particles that were suspended in this liquid carrier are concentrated between them. Once frozen, the sample is freeze-dried to sublime the ice-phase and reveal the material scaffold; its architecture is the negative of the ice crystals which templated it. The cell wall material structure is the result of a self-assembly process. Freeze casting or "ice templating" is a relatively inexpensive procedure and provides a means to mimic complex, efficient natural materials with hierarchical designs over several length-scales. This award supports research to build models, basic design principles and tools that will enable a systematic approach for the design and manufacture of freeze-cast hybrid materials with enhanced performance. These new materials will be of benefit to both individuals and the general public at large through applications that range from energy generation and storage to tissue repair and regeneration.

This research program focuses on the fundamental science and modeling-driven design of freeze-cast hybrid materials. An interdisciplinary team with expertise in modeling, experiment and characterization will address current knowledge gaps and analyze the formation and evolution of the ice phase and ice-templated material architectures generated by the freeze casting process in an attempt to uncover basic physicochemical principles and determine fundamental processing-structure-property correlations. The three research goals are to (1) determine the underlying fundamental materials science and establish a realistic model for ice-crystal nucleation and growth on a well-defined substrate (graphene) during freeze casting; (2) uncover processing-structure-property correlations by combining multiscale computational modeling with experimental approaches; and (3) develop predictive models to identify the most promising processing-additive combinations in order to custom-design and optimize structure formation and performance in the model material system.

Performance_Institution.Name: Dartmouth College - Thayer School of Engineering

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Freeze casting, a process for the manufacture of porous materials by directional solidification and ice templating of typically water-based solutions and slurries, is attracting increasing research interest worldwide; it is also emerging as a commercially viable processing route for the manufacture of novel materials of all classes: polymers, ceramics, metals, and their composites. To address current knowledge gaps in both ice nucleation and growth in the context of freeze casting, we formed an interdisciplinary team with expertise in computational and experimental materials science to explore modeling-based approaches and tools in support of the design of ice-nucleating surfaces and controlled ice crystal growth for the manufacture of materials with new and improved properties.

            Our approach was based on three cores: multiscale theory and modeling, their experimental validation through ex situ and in situ observations of the freeze-casting process, and the careful characterization of ice-templated materials manufactured under well-defined and controlled conditions. Combining forces in the analysis of the formation and evolution of the ice phase and ice-templated material architectures generated by freeze casting, we were able to gain important new insights into the fundamental science of the freeze-casting process.

            The experimental and computational studies of surface energy and topographical effects on the ice-nucleation efficiency of graphene/graphitic and silicon/silicon-oxide substrates highlight experimental challenges; these are due to variations in the quality of graphene-to-substrate adhesion in commercially sourced graphene substrates and present considerable experimental challenges for this material system and an experimental verification of computational results. Additionally, the studies revealed promising opportunities for ice-nucleation control offered by silicon/silicon-oxide substrates due to greater reproducibility and control over the desired surface properties.

            Ice crystal growth phenomena were studied experimentally to parallel the computational effort and observe in 2D in a Hele-Shaw cell, imaged by optical microscopy, the solidification process perpendicular to the direction of the progressing freezing front. Taking advantage of the transparency of purely polymeric material systems, e.g. aqueous alginate solutions, crystal growth and structure formation phenomena could be analyzed and quantified. Parameters for the Phase Field Modeling effort could successfully be obtained from the observations of solidification, phase separation, and structure formation by ice-templating in 2D freezing channels. However, because of the boundary conditions and limited thickness of the 2D system, the microstructure formation is so significantly affected that computational and experimental correlations and trends observed in 2D can only be used to qualitatively, but not quantitatively, predict 3D outcomes such as lamellar spacing or instability formation in bulk materials.

            Robust 3D structure-property-processing correlations that correlate applied cooling rate with pore morphology, on the one hand, and mechanical properties, on the other, were obtained through a systematic structural and mechanical characterization of freeze-cast biopolymers. In these systematic studies of different material systems, also the bi-directional and radial freezing of long/tubular scaffolds were explored, in addition to the more common longitudinal. Property charts were generated to illustrate structure-property-processing correlations between the short pore axis and applied cooling rate, modulus and applied cooling rate, yield strength and modulus, toughness (work to 60% strain) and modulus, for both longitudinally and radially frozen biopolymer scaffolds.

            The intellectual merit of the study includes the discovery of basic physicochemical principles and fundamental processing-structure-property correlations of predictive quality. The fundamental knowledge gained is of interest and broader impact to the larger freeze casting community and enables the selection of the most promising material and processing-parameter combinations for the custom design and manufacture of, for example, new and improved materials for applications that range from tissue regeneration and repair to filtration, catalysis, and energy generation and storage.

            The PI and Co-PIs and their group members were committed to training and professional development. The research effort was fully integrated into their teaching efforts; women and underrepresented minorities were actively recruited and trained. Student engagements have resulted not only in undergraduate education, mentorship training for graduate student, postdoctoral Research Associates and Research Scientists, but also in the design and implementation of new experiments and experimental devices for the use in research and in education, including class projects, and recruiting and outreach activities.

            The project ideally lent itself to the development of new educational programs and activities for the promotion of materials science and engineering through our popular outreach program called “Food for Thought.” Through the manufacture. testing, and tasting of ice-creams, chocolates, cotton candy, and sugar glasses processed at different cooling and solidification rates (‘freezing’), and/or with different heat treatments (‘tempering’), we could, by employing all senses, make tangible to a broad audience the effect of materials processing parameters and their effect on appearance, texture, and flavor. A high school student working in the lab translated the outreach labs into course material for her school, and started together with undergraduate students an educational liquid nitrogen ice cream stand at the local weekly farmers' market.

 


Last Modified: 05/18/2020
Modified by: Ulrike G.K. Wegst
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Freeze casting, a process for the manufacture of porous materials by directional solidification and ice templating of typically water-based solutions and slurries, is attracting increasing research interest worldwide; it is also emerging as a commercially viable processing route for the manufacture of novel materials of all classes: polymers, ceramics, metals, and their composites. To address current knowledge gaps in both ice nucleation and growth in the context of freeze casting, we formed an interdisciplinary team with expertise in computational and experimental materials science to explore modeling-based approaches and tools in support of the design of ice-nucleating surfaces and controlled ice crystal growth for the manufacture of materials with new and improved properties. Our approach was based on three cores: multiscale theory and modeling, their experimental validation through ex situ and in situ observations of the freeze-casting process, and the careful characterization of ice-templated materials manufactured under well-defined and controlled conditions. Combining forces in the analysis of the formation and evolution of the ice phase and ice-templated material architectures generated by freeze casting, we were able to gain important new insights into the fundamental science of the freeze-casting process. The experimental and computational studies of surface energy and topographical effects on the ice-nucleation efficiency of graphene/graphitic and silicon/silicon-oxide substrates highlight experimental challenges; these are due to variations in the quality of graphene-to-substrate adhesion in commercially sourced graphene substrates and present considerable experimental challenges for this material system and an experimental verification of computational results. Additionally, the studies revealed promising opportunities for ice-nucleation control offered by silicon/silicon-oxide substrates due to greater reproducibility and control over the desired surface properties. Ice crystal growth phenomena were studied experimentally to parallel the computational effort and observe in 2D in a Hele-Shaw cell, imaged by optical microscopy, the solidification process perpendicular to the direction of the progressing freezing front. Taking advantage of the transparency of purely polymeric material systems, e.g. aqueous alginate solutions, crystal growth and structure formation phenomena could be analyzed and quantified. Parameters for the Phase Field Modeling effort could successfully be obtained from the observations of solidification, phase separation, and structure formation by ice-templating in 2D freezing channels. However, because of the boundary conditions and limited thickness of the 2D system, the microstructure formation is so significantly affected that computational and experimental correlations and trends observed in 2D can only be used to qualitatively, but not quantitatively, predict 3D outcomes such as lamellar spacing or instability formation in bulk materials. Robust 3D structure-property-processing correlations that correlate applied cooling rate with pore morphology, on the one hand, and mechanical properties, on the other, were obtained through a systematic structural and mechanical characterization of freeze-cast biopolymers. In these systematic studies of different material systems, also the bi-directional and radial freezing of long/tubular scaffolds were explored, in addition to the more common longitudinal. Property charts were generated to illustrate structure-property-processing correlations between the short pore axis and applied cooling rate, modulus and applied cooling rate, yield strength and modulus, toughness (work to 60% strain) and modulus, for both longitudinally and radially frozen biopolymer scaffolds. The intellectual merit of the study includes the discovery of basic physicochemical principles and fundamental processing-structure-property correlations of predictive quality. The fundamental knowledge gained is of interest and broader impact to the larger freeze casting community and enables the selection of the most promising material and processing-parameter combinations for the custom design and manufacture of, for example, new and improved materials for applications that range from tissue regeneration and repair to filtration, catalysis, and energy generation and storage. The PI and Co-PIs and their group members were committed to training and professional development. The research effort was fully integrated into their teaching efforts; women and underrepresented minorities were actively recruited and trained. Student engagements have resulted not only in undergraduate education, mentorship training for graduate student, postdoctoral Research Associates and Research Scientists, but also in the design and implementation of new experiments and experimental devices for the use in research and in education, including class projects, and recruiting and outreach activities. The project ideally lent itself to the development of new educational programs and activities for the promotion of materials science and engineering through our popular outreach program called "Food for Thought." Through the manufacture. testing, and tasting of ice-creams, chocolates, cotton candy, and sugar glasses processed at different cooling and solidification rates (‘freezing’), and/or with different heat treatments (‘tempering’), we could, by employing all senses, make tangible to a broad audience the effect of materials processing parameters and their effect on appearance, texture, and flavor. A high school student working in the lab translated the outreach labs into course material for her school, and started together with undergraduate students an educational liquid nitrogen ice cream stand at the local weekly farmers' market.
